lessonOverview.title: Unit 3 - Lesson 2
structures: A: Have you got any beef?
B: Yes, I have. / No, I haven’t.
A: Has he/she got any milk?
B: Yes, he/she has. / No, he/she hasn’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six foods (beef, lamb, milk, butter, cheese, yoghurt) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show food flashcards. Say: “This is cheese.” Students listen and hold up cards or point in their SB. Extend by asking: “Is it a drink or a food?”
stretchStrategies: Students role-play a “Supermarket Checkout” in pairs. One is the cashier asking “Have you got any…?” / “Has she got any…?” The other answers, adding 1 extra food item not on their list.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about food using “Have you got any...?” / “Has he/she got any...?” and respond with “Yes, I have.” / “No, I haven’t.” / “Yes, he/she has.” / “No, he/she hasn’t.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Use pair cards: one has a shopping list; one has a fridge picture. Ask and answer: “Have you got any…?” “Yes, I have / No, I haven’t.”
stretchStrategies: Students role-play a “Supermarket Checkout” in pairs. One is the cashier asking “Have you got any…?” / “Has she got any…?” The other answers, adding 1 extra food item not on their list.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “Have you got any ___?” / “Yes, I have.” / “No, I haven’t.” and “Has he/she got any ___?” / “Yes, he/she has.” / “No, he/she hasn’t.” to talk about food.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write “Have you got any ___?” and “Has he/she got any ___?” on the board. Do quick pair drills, swapping subject and food.
stretchStrategies: Students role-play a “Supermarket Checkout” in pairs. One is the cashier asking “Have you got any…?” / “Has she got any…?” The other answers, adding 1 extra food item not on their list.

items: Food in syllabi typically Western-centric: banh mi >> bread
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
